awd_titl_txt: Planning: Capacity Building for a New RII Track-1 in Vermont
awd_abstract_narration:
The Vermont State Committee, through a statewide, competitive, open call and review process, selected the research theme centered around the “Study of Online, Collective Knowledge, and Stories” (SOCKS) as best positioned to support the growing technology sector and move forward the RII Track-1 proposal. SOCKS is focusing in the topic of Computational Social Sciences which is properly aligned with the Vermont's Science and Technology Plan.  The planning grant proposal offers an optimal opportunity to achieve the goals set forth by Vermont’s State Committee.  A series of workshops in team science and broader impacts including an "all-hands" meeting that includes the participation of experts in the area as well as diversity of attendees will serve to explore  ideas for the full proposal.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.inst_name: University of Vermont & State Agricultural College
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & STATE AGRICULTURAL COLLEGE

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Vermont & State Agricultural College

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The primary purpose of this planning grant was to strengthen Vermont’s competitiveness for an NSF EPSCoR RII Track-1 award through a series of facilitated activities, and analysis of Vermont’s research capacity and aligned workforce development efforts in STEM.  During this Planning Grant period a rigorous plan was developed and undertaken to strengthen several RII Track-1 programmatic elements that would benefit from additional investigation in the proposal. Through those activities, the future RII Track-1 proposal would be strengthened.  As envisaged, a successful RII Track-1 was awarded the subsequent year.  

Vermont is experiencing growth in the number of technology firms that are in need of an educated workforce, and access to research infrastructure. These needs include cultivating the next generation of STEM workers; attraction and retention of skilled workers; tools that leverage large textual data sets to mine for content; accessible Artificial Intelligence (AI) and machine learning platforms; and the use of computational social science methods to support research and industry growth. While in Vermont there are signs of growing strengths in these areas, a future Track-1 would provide a means for an organized effort with measures and deliverables to catalyze and amplify these distinct efforts into a more concerted and viable mechanism for greater impacts for our researchers, industry, workforce development, and public-private partnerships. The need to review Vermont’s research and workforce development landscape, broaden participation, coalesce stakeholders and researchers to help identify areas for further opportunities, and to set up the capacity for a strong and viable pathway for Vermont to advance in this area, would help inform a future RII Track-1 proposal and its relevance to the region.

PI, Christopher Koliba, led outreach efforts across the state e.g. in-person meetings, remote video conferencing, to help inform best practices and approaches to engage and include as many diverse members as possible across the state into the program and which practices were best suited for optimum impact and success. Broader impacts partners were identified and invited to Team Science Workshops led by external facilitators, a Broader Impacts Workshop led by PI, Koliba, and an All-Hands meeting. In addition, the inclusivity of new and geographically diverse members of the academic community across Vermont was prioritized. During the All-Hands Meeting, researchers provided slam-style presentations and answered questions across disciplines about the path that the project will take. The meeting served as an opportunity for the new research group to meet face-to-face and collaborate.  Team Science Workshops introduced participants questions such as “What is Team Science” and other related topics.  Through facilitated activities, research exchanges and broader impacts discussions, teams started to integrate and function as collaborative and coherent units. The planning period and resulting cohesion led to the production a competitive proposal.  Additional outcomes resulted in a pre-planning period for the Track-1 award, with External Evaluators, who assisted in undertaking immediate steps to get the work launched. These activities included a review of best practices in Team Science, a walk-through of the major elements of the proposal, and reviews of work in progress culminating in a successful Strategic Planning Meeting in August 2023.


Last Modified: 02/15/2024
Modified by: Christopher Koliba
